title: No one expected The Rock to be a star, claims Triple H as he teases who's next
text:
Triple H wants to find the next breakout star (Pictures: Rex/Getty)

Dwayne ‘The Rock’ Johnson was arguably the first to truly transcend the world of WWE, and Triple H thinks the next breakout superstar is waiting in the wings.

Trading his trunks and boots for suits and boardrooms, the company’s chief operating officer – whose real name is Paul Levesque – is the head honcho for the NXT brand and he believe that roster holds the key to an era defining champion.

Speaking at the WWE’s Performance Center in Orlando, Florida, Levesque told Metro.co.uk: ‘I see so many of them [who could be the next big thing]… When you look at Raw and SmackDown with the Seth Rollins, the Sasha Banks, the Alexa Bliss-es, the Braun Strowmans, all these people came from here.

‘They came through these doors, and whether they had a career in this prior or not, the things we taught them being ready for television came from here. That’s a game changing moment.’

To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Of course, Dwayne – who returns on tonight’s launch of Friday Night SmackDown in Los Angeles – wasn’t an instant hit, with his initial debut as Rocky Maivia not quite catching on with fans in 1996.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Similarly, the rise of his career defining rival ‘Stone Cold’ Steve Austin – and Triple H himself – took time to really take off.

‘The funny thing is for a lot of people – when Rocky Maivia walked through the door, nobody went “Oh this guy’s gonna change” – I mean, maybe some people saw it but a lot of people didn’t go “oh this guys gonna change the world and be the biggest movie star ever!” Stone Cold when he walked into the WWE as The Ringmaster, Hunter Hearst Helmsley,’ Levesque pointed out.

‘Do you know who it’s going to be? No you don’t, but you do your best to try and figure it out.

Hollywood Hulk Hogan and The Rock at Wrestlemania X8 (Picture: George Pimentel/WireImage)

‘You didn’t know Rocky Maivia was the guy day one, but a year later you were like, this guy’s got something, right? So, it’s a process but that’s what we’re here for.’

Levesque also took his time to become the legendary and hugely influential star fans know and love today.

However, injuries and a focus on his office role shaping the present and future of the industry means The Game has no plans – or even desire – to make an in-ring return.

‘I don’t know how I would fit it in, and I don’t have the desire right now to fit it in,’ he admitted just months after facing Dave Bautista at WrestleMania 35 in April.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘But you never know. If the right thing comes along and the company needs it or whatever, then I would entertain the idea.’

Instead, Levesque’s priority is shaping WWE’s future through NXT and PC, and with his work for both Raw and SmackDown.

‘People talk about the Attitude Era, they talk about the Ruthless Aggression Era. That new Era is coming. It’s here, it just hasn’t hit yet,’ he promised.

‘The landscape of WWE in this week has changed, totally – and I think that will continue over time. The best refresh and they reimagine themselves and that’s what this company has done year after year after year after year.’

description: We speak to Triple H about the rise of The Rock and who could be the next wrestling champion.
